Award.AwardTitle: IRFP: Sensory Biology of Coral Larvae: The Role of Opsins and Olfactory Receptors in Larval Behavior, Settlement and Metamorphosis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Research Fellowship Program enables U.S. scientists and engineers to conduct nine to twenty-four months of research abroad. The program's awards provide opportunities for joint research, and the use of unique or complementary facilities, expertise and experimental conditions abroad.

This award will support a twenty-four-month research fellowship by Dr. Benjamin Mason to work with Drs. David Miller and Andrew Baird at James Cook University in Townsville, QLD, Australia and Dr. Akihisa Terakita at Osaka City University in Osaka, Japan.
Coral reefs around the world are in a state of decline. The addition of new individuals via recruitment (larval settlement, metamorphosis and survival to maturity) is one factor that is considered critical to the resilience and recovery of coral populations. Habitat selection during settlement plays a critical role in determining whether a coral will survive. Light and chemicals are the dominant cues guiding habitat selection, settlement and metamorphosis, yet the sensory mechanisms responsible for their detection are unknown. This research investigates the sensory mechanisms involved in the detection of chemical and light cues by coral larvae. It utilizes new molecular resources (coral genome and transcriptome databases) to investigate the cellular localization, biochemistry and ecological function of candidate photoreceptor (opsins) and chemoreceptor (olfactory and odorant receptor) genes in coral planulae.

This research establishes molecular bases for the sensory mechanisms involved in larval settlement and metamorphosis, processes critical to the resilience and persistence of coral reefs, and has implications for coral aquaculture, restoration and reef rehabilitation efforts which rely on these processes. Also, due to the ancient phylogenetic origin of corals, this research provides new insights into the evolution of sensory systems (visual, olfactory and taste) in higher organisms, and it offers potential for the discovery of genes and signaling pathways with novel functions and applications.

In addition to advancing our understanding of mechanisms involved in coral settlement and metamorphosis, improving coral reef restoration and providing insight into the evolution of sensory systems, this research will forge international collaboration between the PI and researchers (Drs. David Miller and Andrew Baird) at James Cook University in Townsville, QLD, Australia, (Dr. Akihisa Terakita) at Osaka City University in Osaka, Japan and (Dr. Vladlen Slepak) at the University of Miami, in Miami, FL, USA.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Given recent trends in coral reef degradation, it is essential that we develop a better  understanding of the basic biology underlying processes that will allow these ecosystems to recover and persist through time.  Coral recruitment - the attachment of the sexual offspring of corals (larvae) to the reef and completion of metamorphosis into a polyp - is critical to the resilience and persistence of coral reefs. Recruitment requires attachment to the reef and metamorphosis but also juvenile survival. Habitat selection during attachment is known to affect post-settlement survival, and at least some species have evolved to use a complex hierarchy of cues to ensure that they ‘get it right’ and locate suitable habitat. Light and chemical cues appear to serve as the dominant signals, yet the nature of these cues and the receptors responsible for the detection of light and chemicals remain elusive.

The goal of this research was to develop an improved understanding of the basic sensory biology underlying coral larval behavior, settlement and metamorphosis. Based on emerging genomic evidence, I investigated the role of opsins (the family of photoreceptors responsible for our vision as well as vision in all other known forms of life) and olfactory receptors (a large family of receptors that detect chemicals in the environment) play in these processes.

Even though corals they do not have eyes, they possess a surprisingly large number of opsin photoreceptors. I found six coral opsin genes that encode proteins with features necessary for photoreception; all six are present in coral larvae. To put this in perspective, humans have nine opsin genes, including three cone opsins (sensitive to blue, green and red light) and one rod opsin.

To investigate the function of these predicted opsins, I used genetic tools (molecular cloning) to produce (express) the coral proteins in human embryonic kidney (HEK) cells (immortal cells that can be grown in dishes in the laboratory). I then used biochemical assays (luminescence reporter genes) to investigate chemical changes in the HEK cells upon exposure to light. Of the six opsin-like proteins I identified, we show that five of these behave as classical photoreceptors (i.e., light activated the receptors leading to intracellular changes in cells expressing the coral opsins). Intriguingly, all five appear to be sensitive to blue or blue-green light. We believe that these receptors have evolved to maximize light capture, as blue-green wavelengths of light are most abundant at the surface of the tropical ocean and also penetrate the deepest in seawater.

I also used a similar approach to identify potential coral olfactory receptors. Of these, one receptor detects fucoxanthin (a chemical produced by calcareous red algae found on coral reefs).  This chemical was previously shown to stimulate settlement and metamorphosis of coral larvae.

This research demonstrates the potential application of these approaches for the continuing investigation of coral sensory biology. It also contributed to the development and validation of a novel assay for characterizing photoreceptors. In addition, the coral opsins identified here have implications for the evolution of photoreceptors and may have application in the field of optogenetics – a relatively new form of light-controlled gene therapy for activating and silencing neurons in the brain.

Regarding the initial, overarching goal of this research, the results of this study enhance our understanding of the cell and biochemical processes underlying coral habitat selection, settlement and metamorphosis. This information provides a foundational understanding of the light and chemical requirements that influence these processes.
